I have played several Zynga games and they all seem to be designed from the same mold. Fun at first but then it takes longer and longer to get "energy", buy more "land", get more "animals", build more "building", etc., etc.,.
I have enjoyed these games for a few weeks until the entire game slows down to the point where the only user choice is to start spending real money for virtual "coins", "hearts", or "stars". Somebody needs to explain to me how I can have over 70,000 "coins" but still don't have enough to but a tree or cow, much less buy more property to expand my "homestead".
So simple, with no more land I can't grow more crops, plant more trees, raise more animals and it appears I have reached a point after several weeks where if I want to finish this game I have only one choice- start spending lots of real money (virtual coins don't seem to have much real value, they just keep adding up but are pretty much useless when it comes to buying anything of value). Yes "real money is what it takes to keep this, and many of the other Zynga games rolling.
After playing this game for a few weeks I feel like I've been visiting Las Vegas, you know how that goes, you spend tons of cash BUT THE HOUSE ALWAYS WINS. The tragedy here is this is really a cute and clever concept until greed rears its ugly head.
I would have MUCH preferred this game to be called "FarmVille Lite", and at some point been given the option of just buying it for $10.00 and being done with it and then being able to play it over and over. I feel like Zynga has taken a game app worth $10.00 and decided to make it cost $50.00-$100.00 to play it.
I'm sorry Zynga, I choose not to shoot up with the new virtual drug. Give me a "purchase game for $10.00" option and I'll be happy. Otherwise, next time an app promo says "tops in in app purchases" just SAY NO. Think I'd rather go to Vegas, it's much more fun and when you're done, you're done.

This game is fun. The dungeons are immersive and remind me of traditional MMO dungeons. This is because it feels like a gaming world. There is something tangible to this game: this means you upgrade gear, you upgrade your character stats, and you can change your toon's appearance. It's like other MMOs in that sense. However, there are few gear slots, and, other than weapons, gear is not visible when worn.

This review would have recieved five stars, but it will not because of some bugs: online game play yeilds spotty connections sometimes, the option to view and join current online games does not work, it is not a smooth transition between the game world and the game menus, and there is no in-game friend window because you'll have to use Game Center to invite/add friends to play in your same dungeon instance.

But the game play is very fun. There are some unique twists to the classes available that help to give variety to play styles--my favorite being the summoner who, for lack of a better term, plays God over an army of minions, and a robot who builds laser beams and reflecting walls.

If you like Defender Chronicles and Field Runners, but you love games like WoW and EQ, you would have fun playing Dungeon Defenders. Just be warned: your original $15 to buy the game from the app store gives you four classes/avatars and a mere several instances to choose from. All other content and classes--and there are quite a few--will cost you more money via in-game purchases.

Good thing this is free…

TLDR Version: Dear Developers -- Please, please, please, let me trade my city credits for investment points!!

Long Version: You need "investment points" in order to expand your territory, remove land obstacles like hills, and start certain projects. The game's developers really want you to buy these points from their store, which I understand, but they've gone way too far in that direction. It is nearly impossible to expand your city without shelling out $1 here, $5 there, and so on. City credits accumulate quickly but your city ends up getting bottlenecked because of how hard it is to get investment points without paying real money for them.

This flaw keeps me from enjoying the game as much as I otherwise would (since SimCity is one of my favorite games, but so hard to find for the Mac) and I'll probably stop playing once the interest starts to fade or I get too frustrated from having to pay $5 every time I want to grow my city. If the developers would make it easier to get investment points, I'd rate 5 stars and probably never stop playing while my real life goes to crap. (Can't ... shower ... Must ... reroute ... trucks ... and ... build ... another ... park ...)

I'm not saying it should be as easy as earning city credits, since I would have been more than willing to pay $15 or $20 to get the game instead of going freemium. The developers should make money off their work. But the difficulty in acquiring investment points is set too high -- it doesn't build loyalty and to be honest it's getting pretty frustrating.

Why not give investment points along with energy when completing the missions, or better yet: Establish a bank where I can buy investment points with my city credits! I have five million city credits, but nothing to do with them since I can't expand without paying more money. Why not let me exchange two million city credits for twenty investment points? That change alone would make this game nearly perfect, and keep me playing for a long time to come.

Okay, first thing to address: I almost didn't get this because I have an ipad mini, and a lot of prior reviews said it didn't work. However, I love this game so much that I decided to try it anyways. I buy apps with survey rewards (quick thoughts app), so I figured I wouldn't actually lose any real money.

The game DOES work on my Mini. There was one time that it closed, which was the beginning of the cutscene immediately after the tutorial stage. Since then, working perfectly! If you have trouble, double tap your home button and close all other running apps.

Now, on to the game. The only differences between this and the console/pc versions are: less varied maps, slightly reduced graphics, and price. This is by far one of the best things you can by on the App Store and I will always support good ports like this, because I want more of them!

Controls work great, however they take a minute or two to get used to. Sometimes you may send a soldier a space or two away from where you wanted, but if you're careful this should never happen.

Graphics-wise, the game looks great even without a retina display. There is very little frame rate loss during character movement, although there is noticeable stutter at times, especially when there is explosions or lots of activity.

In closing, this game is a must-have for anyone who wants more than just Fruit Ninja or in app purchase games that drain your wallet. This one time price of $20 is worth every penny. Thanks to the xcom folks for this one!

This is not a bad game. It's no SimCity, but it comes pretty close. Since it's a free game, with little things you can buy with real money in it, it's another one of those freemium games, but that doesn't make it bad. If anything, there's something mildly enjoyable about watching a city grow because of business and capitalism.

So here's some good points about it.

It's Free.

It's entertaining, if you don't mind waiting in real time to earn a lot of money.

It keeps track of how much you earn, even when the app is closed, or not running.

Here's some of the bad stuff though.

There's some bugs.

You have to post to Facebook/twitter or what have you, in order to actually build anything cool.

It's a freemium game.

The freemiums are almost game-breaking. Instantly giving you a butt-load of coins and 'investment points' so that you can build your Super Stadium feels a bit like cheating, since you didn't really have to work for the stuff it took to build it.

All in all though, it's not a bad game, and it's good for killing half an hour every few hours.

If you love games that make you think and that always give you something new to think about, buy this game.  The learning curve is steep, but climbing up the hill is alot of fun too.  Complete victory usually requires achieving some objective while suffering less than a specified percentage friendly casualties and inflicting a certain percentage of enemy casualties within a specified period of time.  You have to solve a variety of tactical and strategic problems to achieve a balanced result.  So the learning curve not only includes getting used to command interface; it also requires some hard-headed analysis and the willingness to take a few risks during a game.  There are dozens of different ways to approach a battle, to which corresponds a hefty set of possible commands that takes a while to learn.  The command interface is fairly intuitive.   But successful strategic and tactical problem solving requires more than an intuitive feel or familarity with first-person shoot'm ups..  Fortunately, you can experiement by re-playing the same battle multiple times.  The artificial intelligence powering the game is very good.  You don't have to tell your soldiers everything, and enemy soldiers are capable always capable of surprising you with a move you may not have anticipated.  If you like history, there is a whole other level to this game.  The in-game campaigns strive for hisroical authenticity. I like the graphics.  Battle fields contain  many details that make a difference,  You have to study them.  Battle sounds carry information not just ambience.  Customer service is great too. this virtual city game has some of the staples, particularly those of modern free apps; resource management- currency comes in two forms, the other, more valuable form that allows more is more difficult to attain (and both are available for purchase with real money), environment, population, buildings and activities that take real time to complete, and tasks for you to complete to help your city move along the way but also at times try to motivate you to buy costly things.

this game is more enjoyable, however, and isnt too difficult to manage without pressure of spending real money. i say this because it can keep you occupied literally every few minutes because the game operates on contracts you buy to get tasks done that often earn profit and EXP and other items…. more on those items in a bit. and these contracts can literally last only a couple minutes. they can last longer, but you can always choose the quicker option.

anyways, these items. that's one thing that knocked off a star for me. to hire the people necessary for the contracts, you have to collect these items from them that you get at random from certain tasks. the thing is, since it's at random, you can go awhile without getting them. even if you do the specifc tasks required for the item, it doesn't mean you'll get it. this can mean waiting awhile for chance. for example, you may need to hire a referee to open a sports arena. say you need three items for the ref (i cant remember on the top of my head, making this up): a yellow card, a whistle, and a jersey. i havent gotten around to a sports arena yet and have already picked up about 60 yellow cards. meanwhile, i have like 3 buildings that have been waiting to open since nearly the beginning of the game, and i still cant open because i cant get the items.
this can be frustrating, impeding, and obnoxious. it seems to be a bit of a ploy-- you either have to keep building the things that will try to get you the items, forcing you to need to expand/etc, thus needing more money (thus possibly spending real money), or just going ahead and dropping your actual cash to speed things up.

the game can always keep you occupied with little collections, but it can get old when you want to be able to start doing other things.

the graphics are decent but nothing amazing. there are some things that are blurry and pixelated, even without you zooming in. once you've had a lot of buildings/contracts going, it can be rather demanding to have to click on all the buildings to collect profit. it got to the point for me where it'd take me over five minutes. do people really want to spend their time having to deal with that on a game? i had low tolerance for it; there is an option to 'collect all profits immediately,' but it costs those rare country bucks, which the game really wants you to spend actual money on.
